awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Chronological Modeling and Pictograph Stratigraphy
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will study the chronology of painted murals in southwest Texas, one of the oldest and most complex art forms in the Americas. Strong parallels exist between the hunter-gatherer belief systems portrayed in these U.S.-based murals and the myths and cosmologies of later Mesoamerican agriculturalists. These parallels suggest deep prehistoric origins. Although researchers maintain that complex concepts persisted across time and across cultural, linguistic, and geographical boundaries, they lack well-dated archaeological evidence to support their argument. This project will utilize radiocarbon dating to establish the age of Pecos River style production in the context of this hypothesized Archaic core system. The investigators will examine changes over time in these murals, including iconography, mural production, and geographic distribution. This study will add significantly to an understanding of how past cultures managed social identity, territory, mobility, labor organization, and graphic communication. The project will train graduate students, college interns, and high school students in chemistry and new technologies used in archaeology, addressing a national need for providing students with experience in interdisciplinary research, STEM, and team-based projects. 

Newly developed scientific dating methods can now provide the accuracy and precision to date the material and place it within the context of material culture, socioeconomic reorganization, climate change, fluctuating population densities, and extra-regional influences. The investigators will conduct a formal analysis  to document and describe diagnostic pictographs, determine paint application order through a stratigraphic study using digital microscopy and the construction of Harris matrices, and examine spatial patterning using GIS. Based on these data, they will collect 60 paint samples from 10 murals for plasma oxidation and accelerator mass spectrometry radiocarbon dating. Results will inform research into possible drivers for the emergence and decline of the style. The investigators will use the results to model the timing of the introduction and development of complex l concepts which also are present in later Mesoamerican traditions. This will address a cognitive aspect of hunter-gatherer complexity often overlooked by studies focusing on social organization, technology, and subsistence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

With this NSF-funded project, our archaeological team has built a chronological model for one of the oldest and most complex art forms in the Americas, the Pecos River style pictographs of southwest Texas. We have learned when the painting of these murals began, how long the style persisted, and when this painting activity ceased. This ability to place rock art in a chronological context allows an inventory of images to be studied together with excavated cultural remains from a given archaeological period. It also informs possible drivers for the emergence and decline of pictograph production, including environmental, social, and extra-regional cultural influences. With this information, we are beginning to understand the timing and development of core cosmological concepts visually expressed in Pecos River style murals and their participation in a pan-Mesoamerican Archaic core belief system. Pecos River style murals may represent the oldest extant example of this ancient cosmology.

Based on 40 direct paint dates (12 additional dates pending) and 25 indirect oxalate dates, this is the most comprehensive scientific dating of a pictograph style anywhere in the world. By utilizing independent methods to date two different materials, we ensured the accuracy and reliability of the age results obtained.  We used plasma oxidation to extract organic carbon from the paint samples for accelerator mass spectrometry radiocarbon dating. We also isolated overlying and underlying oxalate mineral accretions associated with paint layers to obtain minimum and maximum radiocarbon ages. Chronological modeling of results using a simple phase model at 95% probability suggests that the painting style began between 5890-5415 cal BP (3945-3470 cal BC) and ended between 1495-1045 cal BP (455-905 cal AD). Pecos River style painting persisted for at least 4,000 years and within that time motifs associated with the Archaic core, such as complementary dualism, cyclical time, and a multilayered universe, span the entire production of the murals. Many of these motifs are recognized and interpreted by elders in Indigenous communities today.

Using digital microscopy to study the painting sequence or technical history of Pecos River style murals, we learned that the artists strictly adhered to a specific paint application order, even for those spanning more than 100 feet (30 meters). They applied the black paint in the mural before applying the red, then they applied yellow, and finally white. Through this painting sequence, figures within the mural became interwoven like a complex tapestry, thus demonstrating that Pecos River style murals are not a random collection of images, but complex, single, compositions. The radiocarbon data not only supports this hypothesis but demonstrates that the rule governing color application order persisted throughout the 4,000 years of PRS production.

 

BROADER IMPACTS

This collaborative project involves Texas State University and Shumla Archaeological Research & Education Center. Our partnership has resulted in research interactions and idea exchange between Texas State University faculty and students with the staff at Shumla Archaeological Research & Education Center, as well as the broader community, including Indigenous groups in Texas and Mexico. Texas State is an R2 (Doctoral University: High Research Activity) Hispanic-Serving Institution. Shumla is a non-profit organization working to preserve and study the rock art of the Lower Pecos along the US/Mexico border. Together we have trained graduate students, college interns, and high school students in chemistry and new technologies used in archaeology, addressing a national need for providing students with experience in interdisciplinary research, STEM, and team-based projects.

Our methods have digitally preserved in perpetuity the Pecos River style murals included in this study through GigaPan panoramic photographs, high-resolution figure photography, and digital-layered illustrations replicating the painting sequence followed by the original artists. This graphic data, along with our results, will be curated by Shumla and Texas State University and will be available for scholars conducting research in the Lower Pecos, future virtual and physical exhibitions, and the creation of educational materials and curricula. The results of this collaborative project are furthering knowledge into the origins and tenacity of myth, graphic communication systems among foragers, sound methods for dating rock paintings globally, and placing rock art within a temporal context alongside other aspects of the archaeological record.
